author: {'steamid': '76561197985314446', 'num_games_owned': 666, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1611626271}
review:
Rime is a very stylish exploration game with some puzzles along the way. 

Rime has a cartoon-like art style and I think it looks very nice. The art style gives it a nice relaxing feel, yet the game
can still give off a multitude of feelings and emotions. In my opinion the art style also works because the main character
you play as is a child

Rimes soundtrack is nothing really to speak of. The soundtrack does fit well with the game but it does not stand out on it's own.

Since there is no dialogue the only interesting characters to me were the fox (because the fox was super cute) and the sentinels
because they had a cool design. however the game doesnt dive too far into either.

There are two main gameplay elements; puzzles and platforming. The puzzles aren't to difficult, you might get stuck for a minute
or so but then it's easy to figure out. Thats not a ding against a game unless it tries to be difficult. This game isn't trying to
stump you. I feel like the puzzles here are just to add variety of gameplay and it works fine. Thecontrol for the platofmrer could 
be better, sometimes i feel like I am not jumping where i thought I'd be. Thankfully the game isn't a percision platformer so some loose
controls doesn't harm the gameplay.

I liked the overall feels of the game and I really enjoyed the ending scene. 

I didn't like that the game doesn't change over the 10ish hours it took me to beat. The puzzles don't get harder nor does the platforming become harder or different.
As a result the gameplay can get boring as you get closer to the end of the game. 

Overall the game is a fine game. It doesn't push the envelope or attempt to do something new. It does what it tries to do and I can't blame it for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198362619594', 'num_games_owned': 15, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1651701782}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025655870', 'num_games_owned': 781, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1611443259}
review:
Such powerful interactive storytelling. Reminiscent of Ico, Journey and Spirited Away amongst others, RiME's puzzles take second place to the story embedded into the gameplay and little details placed here and there for the player to get invested in. 

It invites you to take a moment and ask yourself: What am I doing right now? Why am I doing it? What does it mean? And these simple questions make you draw a picture that little by little one unveils with a twist (for some) at the very end. If you have been paying attention, you will feel the warm feeling of melancholic resolution. If you have just been focusing on the puzzles and a bit of foreshadowing here and there, you will be flooded with emotions as a wave of cold salty water runs down your spine. Regardless of the way you play it, the ending does not disappoint. What's more, I believe it may make you want to go through it all one more time.

If you can, avoid all spoilers and just buy the game. Enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056902770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 294, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1541529726}
review:
"I need a bigger key..." - the boy, probably.

Rime is an action puzzle game without the action element.
So just a puzzle game?
No, I know what i said, your character moves as if part of an action game but has to solve puzzles in order to process.
A great cell shaded look and good shot-composition foward the story of this boy that stranded on this strange and whimsical island must uncover what happend to him in a narrative that comunicates theese feelings to you without using a single word.
The only complaint is that the game has very little content for the 35$ pricetag.

Ahestetically pleasing and with a good blend of pacing and setpieces is a short bittersweet game that is a positive experience to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012417415', 'num_games_owned': 1290, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1610886673}
review:
Una obra de arte repleta de sensaciones, todo est√° cuidado al m√≠nimo detalle... todo encaja a la perfecci√≥n... Si, es un juego de exploraci√≥n y puzzles, pero es mucho m√°s que eso! es una historia que te tocar√° el alma!

Empezamos en una playa, donde parece ser que hemos naufragado y nos tocar√° explorar y ver qu√© ha pasado. Al poco tiempo encontraremos un peque√±o y precioso zorro que nos guiar√° toda la partida y lo dicho, a explorar y resolver puzzles.

El juego es precioso, toda la partida he estado parando a contemplar los paisajes, el cielo, las puestas de sol, la noche estrellada... es una preciosidad. La m√∫sica a su vez acompa√±a de manera magistral y te llena de emociones, que al final es de lo que va este juego, te har√° sentir desde el principio en un c√∫mulo de sensaciones que ser√° como un torbellino que remover√° todo tu ser por dentro.

Como punto negativo, el control es un poco tosco con los cambios de c√°mara que se marca pero nada que empa√±e el resultado final.

En resumen, un juego que te va a llegar al coraz√≥n.

review: One of the best games ever made. The art and the music are very well done throughout the entire game. It seems very abstract at the start but it winds up having a very memorable story that slowly reveals itself through gameplay and art. It reminds me of Shadow of the Colossus and Ico. I wish there were more games like this.

sem a necessidade de di√°logos, nem narra√ß√µes, onde nos permite explorar uma ilha vasta cheia de colet√°veis para juntar e assim guiados por uma raposa descobrir mais da historia do lugar e tamb√©m do protagonista,
Jogo que na √©poca dos seu lan√ßamento veio extremante mal otimizado, mas que hoje, acompanhando as atualiza√ß√µes, se tornou um jogo que alem de lindo exibe uma √≥tima performance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287262459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1072, 'last_played': 1610300122}
review: Quite the beautiful game and story. The environments are gorgeous, creative, and diverse and provide a good amount of exploration for those who like to meander through rather than immediately follow the path. Puzzles are fun and generally direct, though the real challenge lies in scouring each stage for all the collectables. Love the art style and the music pairs well with the visuals and story beats for evoking emotion. A wonderful experience overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561199060161682', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1610083346}
review:
6.5/10

RiMe is a par game that makes a lot more sense after you reach the ending. If you haven't already played Ico, Journey, or The Last Guardian, prioritize those over this one.

This game feels very much like a mash up of Fumito Ueda playstation games (mostly Ico 2001), and Journey 2012. It has the speechless protagonist of Ico, the green glowing objects of The Last Guardian, and a musical score reminiscent of Journey.

Unfortunately the only new ground RiMe strikes is at the very end in how it explains (loosely) the world of the game. It feels very much like a fan made Ico, and while that is not a problem if it had been of equal quality, it largely felt derivative and less polished mechanically. The soundtrack for RiMe is incessantly performing the background in a way that felt like the game feared allowing the player to soak in the atmosphere without constant musical mood setting. Introspection is firmly replaced by an unrelenting (albeit nice) string orchestra. The sound that defines Fumito Ueda games is silence, and this game has none of that to offer.

This is not a bad game, but unfortunately it falls just below interesting for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119408009', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1604263040}

review:
En lo art√≠stico es una pasada, no hace falta decir mucho m√°s con eso. Genial la ambientaci√≥n y unos escenarios muy imaginativos e inmersivos, as√≠ como la m√∫sica. 

En lo jugable, es una mezcla de walking simulator, plataformas y puzzles, sencillito tirando a facil√≥n. Eso s√≠, el dise√±o de niveles y escenarios un 10.

La historia en mi opini√≥n es una buena idea no del todo bien ejecutada, aunque tambi√©n es un concepto complicado de abarcar.

En mi opini√≥n no me lo pillar√≠a por su precio original (no me malinterpret√©is, no me parece mal juego ni mucho menos, y me parece que hay un curro monumental detr√°s. Sin embargo, yo al menos me esperar√≠a a una rebaja, o lo comprar√≠a por su precio original para apoyar a la industria espa√±ola, pero aceptando que no hay contenido como para amortizarlo).

author: {'steamid': '76561198169098649', 'num_games_owned': 1543, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1119, 'last_played': 1609117646}
review:
Such a gem. It made me remember ICO, so if you liked it, you'll probably like this one as well.
Aesthetically, the game is beautiful and the music is fairly compelling. Plot wise, the game is captivating and it makes you totally hooked into it, such feels while playing it. The developers made a really well job with this game, so I cannot stress my thanks enough for this jewel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989384095', 'num_games_owned': 833, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1607281647}
review:
Il en vaut le coup!! Largement!

Il m'a beaucoup rappel√© Journey sur certains points sans en √™tre une p√¢le copie comme des sites de jeux videos l'indiquent...
J'ai trouv√© les paysages fabuleux et les puzzles relaxants.

Sc√©nario: Vous incarnez un petit gar√ßon qui se r√©veille sur une plage d'une ile myst√©rieuse, celle l√† m√™me qui est pr√©sente sur la jaquette du jeu.
La magie est omnipr√©sente et rend le jeu totalement impr√©visible tout comme l'histoire.
En clair on ne sait pas trop ou l'on veut nous emmener mais comme les paysages sont sublimes, on est loin de se forcer √† continuer.

Graphismes: Identiques √† ceux de Journey, ils permettent au jeu d'instaurer une atmosph√©re et une ambiance tr√©s particuli√©re. Apaisant, le jeu peut aussi prendre une tournure plus noire √† certains passages, le tout gr√¢ce √† un effet de lumi√©re et de textures semblables aux derniers dessins anim√©s.

Difficult√©: Il n'y en a pas. La r√©solution des puzzles pourra prendre plus ou moins de temps selon votre sens de la logique.

Dur√©e de vie: 7 heures pour l'histoire principale. Le double pour finir le jeu √† 100% et d√©bloquer les succ√©s.

Prix: Moins de 10 euros en soldes. Correct.

En r√©sum√©, ce jeu a emprunt√© les grandes lignes de Journey sans en √™tre une p√¢le copie. Il est diff√©rent de par son histoire car il y a bien une histoire et une conclusion qui permet de donner un v√©ritable sens au p√©riple du gar√ßon. Une note touchante d'ailleurs.
Je conseil.

review:
Rime es un juego competente pero no carente de fallos. Tiene un problema en su conexi√≥n v√≠deo juego-hisotoria. Pretende contarte una historia sin decirte absolutamente nada, intentando que cuando se revele el final sientas alguna emoci√≥n. En mi caso, esto no ha sucedido ya que lo que juegas poco tiene que ver con la historia que se intenta narrar.

Como v√≠deo juego est√° muy bien, sus puzles hacen son lo suficientemente sencillos como para que no te atasques y lo suficientemente variados como para que no te resulten repetitivos. Mec√°nicamente tampoco tiene problemas, es un juego de plataformas que est√° bien resuelto y si fallas en alg√∫n salto o similar, es muy posible que sea por t√∫ culpa. ¬°Compra Rime, compra! Yo no me arrepent√≠ y t√∫ tampoco lo har√°s. Su mayor problema tal vez, sea que pretende ser m√°s emotivo de lo que realmente consigue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066528536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1606491283}
review:
I bought this game for 1 euro in a steam key shop and didnt know what to expect. First impression was cute platformer with a nice artstyle but this game is more than that. It tells you a beatifully crafted and touching story in 6 only hours. 

Gameplay is okay, graphics are beautiful even on low settings (which i had to chose because apparently an i5 4460 and gtx 1060 6gb arent good enough).

My only complaint is the optimization really.  If you can get it discounted anywhere on the internet this game is really worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031996920', 'num_games_owned': 405, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1591488633}
review:
Description: RiME is an exploration puzzle game developed by Tequilla Works and published by Grey Box Six Foot in 2017. Play as a young boy who finds himself washed up on shore of a mysterious island. With the help of a mysterious fox he must explore the island and learn the mysteries of where he is and why he is there.

Graphics/Art Style: I really like the art style in RiME. It really holds up well considering the game is over 3 years old. Characters have a somewhat unique look to them, and the environment is absolutely gorgeous. From the starting beach all the way to the end of the game, every environment you encounter is breathtakingly beautiful. Detailed landscapes inspire a sense of wonder and awe, dark ominous areas instill a sense of dread, and ancient abandoned buildings make you wonder where you are and what happened in the ancient civilization that existed long ago.

Audio/Music: The music in RiME is exceptional. It is a great mix of insightful, somber and tranquil. I added the soundtrack it to my spotify playlist immediately after finishing the game.

Controls: RiME controls fairly well. My only complaint is that the character seems to lock on to some ledges very strongly, which can lead to you falling to your death when trying to jump somewhere else. I only had one or two deaths that I attributed to the controls, which is acceptable.

Gameplay/Difficulty: The puzzles of RiME are fairly simplistic. I like this, as overly complex puzzles could easily detract from the story, which is the main highlight of this game. Although they are simplistic, there is a lot of variety, and none of the various mechanics are overused at any point of the game.

Replayability: Sadly there is little replayability in RiME. Unless you missed some collectables and want to go back and find them later, once you beat the game you will be more or less done.

Writing/Story: The story of RiME is where this game truly shines. Unfortunately, due to spoilers I can‚Äôt say much about it, but what I will say is that I haven‚Äôt been this emotionally invested in a puzzle game for a long time.

Length/Price/Value: I was able to beat RiME in 5.3 hours, and I collected roughly half of the collectable items in the game. Purchased for $10.59, totaling roughly $2 an hour. While this a little spendy, I still enjoyed the game quite a bit.

Recommendation: RiME is a great game for those who like a good story quality mixed into their puzzle game. I enjoyed it a lot, although some may want to wait for it to go on sale before buying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120759889', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 752, 'last_played': 1605673296}
review:
Rime is one of those beautiful games that you don't understand anything at the beginning, and learn everything on the fly.  Similar to INSIDE in that regard, but that's where the similarities end.

You play (mostly) as a young "boy" (in quotes because i found it ambiguous) and get to follow a fox around that shows you where you need to go for most of the game.  Simple concept, and its shown in beautiful cell shaded style.

But it gets much deeper than that.  Who is this mysterious cloaked individual?  What are these creatures?  What is this world?  Many questions will arise in the course of playing the game, and most will be answered, but, like all good games,. some is left to interpretation.

Much like To The Moon, If I explained what makes this game so good and wonderful to play, I would have to give away what makes it so good in the first place.  Go in blind, and understand that things are not always as they seem.

Pros:
-Absolutely amazing and brilliantly crafted visuals from start to finish
-Great soundtrack, definitely worth a listen to
-a good story with a twist, open to interpretation
-You can play with the fox!
-You can light things with your voice!
-Experimentation is encouraged, as you can't truly "die"
-Exploration is heavily encouraged, especially if you want to find and collect everything
-its very hard to get truly lost, as every time you do or can, the fox comes along to save the day and show you where to go to proceed

Cons:
-Ultra settings will require something akin to a gamer PC or laptop
-Controls can be a bit finniky at times, sometimes they can mess up and require a restart of the game to fix
-Forced camera parts while you're running on thin pathways can be very annoying

I highly recommend this game if you want a fun little adventure with as touching story and absolutely amazing visuals.  I cannot stress that enough, this game is gorgeous from start to finish, and only gets better.

If you're looking for a mindless game where all you do is kill people and get points for it, this isn't for you.

This is a prime example of a game being art with a deeper message that can and does take everything you know and shine a new perspective on it.  Much like Superliminal does.

If the trailer interests you, i guarantee you will enjoy thew game.  it deserves to be played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043642717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1602728236}
review:
Achievements: Not unreasonable to 100%.  Most achievements are easily missed, but a chapter select option is unlocked after beating the game.  

RiME is a gorgeous game with compelling music and visuals.  Each environment, each creature, each towering structure is so beautifully crafted.  The areas feel unique, the scenery is stunning.  Unfortunately, this is all that RiME really brings to the table.  Personally, I could not find the fun in this game.  The puzzles were dull (but pretty!), the platforming was stiff, the walk speed was much too slow, and the story felt disappointingly ordinary.  

Looking at the screenshots on the store page gives the feeling of such grand, expansive environments.  "Adventure" and "Exploration" are two of the top tags describing RiME.  One could certainly be led to believe this game is full of sprawling stories, diverse places, and lots of content.  This is not the case.  RiME is a linear game.  The environments are giant, but they're also empty.  The only thing earned by exploring them is the occasional collectible.  Some of the areas are designed in ways that are confusing, forcing the player to backtrack large distances or redo long climbs.  I feel there was more of a focus on aesthetics than good level design.  This, plus the lack of any maps, means there's a huge potential to get lost while looking for the one place the game wants you to go.  

Navigating the vastness of RiME is not fun.  The run speed is slow while the climbing is clunky and stiff.  I don't feel compelled to search the lands for secrets when it takes so long to get around.  There's no sprint button.  There's a roll, but it's slow and seems useless.  Jumping while running removes your momentum.  For me, a game with long walks needs something to keep my attention along the way-- whether that's combat or environmental hazards or just a button I can press to make me feel like I'm going faster.  

RiME could be called relaxing, but it could just as easily be called boring.  The puzzles are bland.  Don't get me wrong, they feature very strong and creative imagery that feels satisfying to watch unfold.  They are still very bland, though.  The solutions are simple, the same mechanics are repeated throughout the game with little variation or complications.  There's no challenge to them whatsoever.  

In terms of value, I think RiME is overpriced.  One playthrough-- wherein which I got lost several times-- took only 5 hours.  The rest of my playtime was spent getting the achievements I had missed.  Five hours of content-- regardless of how scenic it was-- should be cheaper than $30.  

Overall, I am disappointed by RiME.  I enjoyed the visuals, the symbolism, the breathtaking music, but I did not enjoy the game.  For me, it just wasn't very fun.  If there was more to the puzzles, more to the lore, more fluidity towards the platforming elements, then I would be more inclined to recommend it.  Otherwise, if you're still interested, I'd recommend you only consider buying it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072266629', 'num_games_owned': 897, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1605483098}

author: {'steamid': '76561198121112670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 278, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1605505176}
review:
RIME is an adventure puzzle game about a boy moving about an island yelling at flames, statues, and pots and finding keys in the process.  Beat it in 6.5ish hours taking my time, using a game controller.  Difficulty is easy to moderate.

- This is one of those wordless 'surreal story' art games.  That said the story is... There?  It's there.  Expect to have your heart stabbed if you're the sensitive type.  If you're not the sensitive type...  Um...  Yeah, surreal story art game right here!  Enjoy the lush game play experience!!

- Speaking of, the game play involves jumping from ledge to ledge and climbing stuff or grabbing items in order to open doors to get to the next area.  It's pretty loose in terms of direction and you can tell your helper to sod off and explore all you want per area, jumping recklessly into pits or throwing yourself at rocks to find hidden paths.

- Each chapter is unique and provides different challenges and enemies, however most of the puzzles revolve around the 'push box, get key for door, jump and cling to ledges' formula.  Once you beat the game, you can access each chapter individually.

- The graphics are pretty and the camera is very well balanced.  I normally die of motion sickness in games, and fully expected to here, but the worst I had it was in the underwater levels, and it wasn't that bad at all.  Took a ginger pill and I was fine for hours.  Turn up brightness for the darker levels if needed.

- Music?  Music's pretty and atmospheric.  

- There's a fox!  Fraka-kaka-kaka-kaka-kow!

- You pet the fox!  AND hug it!  (Once, anyway)

- There are many inventive achievements to get and trinkets to collect that unlock all sorts of fun stuff like outfits.

- On the very last scene the camera was a bit laggy, like my processor could barely withstand the experience.  And this is a beefy comp.  If you experience this issue, try turning VSync off.  I also fabulously went out of my way to glitch the fox so he's invisible for cut scenes and the pigs so they were stuck in walls.  Tried really hard to get the boy stuck on multiple occasions, almost succeeded once, but he's good at getting free (better than his animal friends).  So the game isn't glitch proof.  Not that any of those glitched killed the adventure for me.



If you're into games like the ICO trilogy or Uncharted series, Rime is a very nice, entertaining adventure puzzle game with very loose story elements, an atmospheric soundtrack, and replayability.   I beat it, the ending didn't do much for me, but I'll play it again and very likely 100% the lot for fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198967541949', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 477, 'last_played': 1690181177}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042055174', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1639447141}
review: Pretty graphics, too bad about the gameplay. Exploration is decently fun, but the "puzzles" (can you even call them that?) are wildly uninspired, and all the mechanics are pure jank. Bird levels exposed too many bugs (a bird is going to snatch me out of the sky while I'm inside a completely enclosed dome? really?) and far too much horridly boring level design, I quickly ran out of patience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034348551', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1605305044}
review:
Aesthetically, I adored this game. The cute, colourful and bright art style is right up my alley. It's so pleasant to look at, I sometimes stood on a cliff just to see how the landscape changed as the day became night.

I didn't like the music, as I found it too same-y, but I didn't hate it either.

The gameplay is decent enough. The puzzles are very easy, but that's okay because the game is pretty clearly meant to be relaxing and sentimental. Wish the kid were a little faster, but again, adequate.

Now. The story.

I'm sorry to say the story is where it lost me.

First of all, we don't spend enough time with the characters to develop a strong emotional attachment to them. Like, at some point a "character" we have sort of been solving puzzles with for less than a hour disappears, and the kid throws himself to the ground wailing in despair. And I'm kinda feeling, well, that was unfortunate, but I'm not exactly feeling like crying here. Sir, I hardly know you.

The goals are also too vague and unclear. You move forward because it's a game and you are supposed to move forward, but there is no real sense of *why*. It's a desert island, it's not like you are going to get back to civilization by diving into underground caves. In fact, given that the first stages are like a beautiful paradise with plenty of food and the chance to be spotted by passing ships, while the later stages are creepy and dangerous and hidden away, story-wise it would make more sense for the kid to remain where he is and build a shelter.

Of course, in the end this logic is meaningless, because...

[SPOILERS]

...the story turns out to be a metaphor/dream.

Unfortunately, that still fails to move me. Partly because by the time of the Reveal I've already been moving forward for no given reason for 4 stages, so it feels a little too late. Partly because, well...

I didn't know why so many indie developers are obsessed with loss. If you are playing an artistic indie game, it's a pretty safe bet that the story is about death, either your own or a loved one's. It's so widespread that it turned what is supposed to be an emotional journey into *routine*. I'm sorry, but at this point I consider it an unexpected plot-twist if they don't die/aren't Dead all Along.

Given how predictable that theme is, a game that follows it has to do something really special to shine. For example, LIMBO has very creative puzzles and a 100% unique presentation.

Nothing RiME does feels special enough. It's an above average game, but not a great one, so it can't overcome the burden of "I've already seen this trope many, many times".

review: I really wanted to give this a good review, for all it's flaws I enjoyed this.... up until the last 5 minutes. It's not important"

author: {'steamid': '76561198014894080', 'num_games_owned': 1195, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1604364834}
review:
Rime is an adventure-platformer-walking simulator with a few puzzles. A beautiful game with great graphics and enviroment, the music was really good too. The best part of this game is the sad story that slowly unravels, and near the end you realize what is going on. In the game there isn't any dialogue or any language. In the 1st run a lot of things seems kinda insignificant, but in the second run if you think (with the knowledge of the end of the game) about what you so in the game early everything makes sense , and you find a lot of symbolism. Rime is a 5 chapter game, and in each one of this is talking about the 5 steps of grief.  Recommend it for sure, hidden diamond!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985945655', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1605111072}
review:
Beautiful, sad - this is a Ghibliesque game/piece of art that made me cry a bit. 

Another great source of 4k wallpaper, and the attention to detail (the painstaking animation of the kid is a standout, especially when he tries to run quickly through water) is really quite amazing. This is one game that I enjoyed doing a second play through with an achievement guide (I used [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1562601561] this one [/url]) to get all the little secrets as they are well worth seeing, and add some lovely touches to the story and ending.

review: This kinda feels like a rehashed version of Journey. It's well done, but so many ideas are straight copies, the whole thing feels like a big homage.... and unfortunately isn't quite as well polished (story-wise) so feels slightly empty because of it. However well done to the makers, although it's a bit boring there's plenty of room in the world for art like this... as it's still a beautiful game and the soundtrack is gorgeous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026806776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1604284123}
review:
RiME speaks a language that's familiar to gamers; there's a castaway boy on an island with magical ancient ruins. The graphics, and the non-verbal protagonist, bear a strong similarity to [i]Wind Waker[/i].  Here, there's a simple puzzle that teaches you the concept needed to solve a harder problem.  Over there, a secret area and a collectable. Further on, some portentous hieroglyphs and a forced-perspective puzzle. Elsewhere, climbing segments and sliding blocks.  A mysterious watcher and an enigmatic animal guide fill out the familiar, comfortable tropes.

And yet...

Even early on, RiME begins hinting to the experienced gamer that not everything here is the well-trod ground it appears to be.  Something deeper and more consequential is being built up. RiME is good at keeping its cards close to its chest, however.   Recognition that there is some kind of metaphor in play comes early, but full realisation is held off at length.  The result is a powerful and compelling tale, told in the language of games, that should not be spoiled.  Avoid spoilers for this one.

To me, this was a beautiful, perfect gaming experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198371329974', 'num_games_owned': 167, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1603478492}
review:
I went into this expecting a two hours beautiful game, I did get the beautiful part but for even longer! 

Positives: 
+ Deep story that connects together at the end 
+ Beautiful world (that got me excited to take screenshots) 
+ The puzzles are fun, something about the climbing is just fun 
+ You get connected to the characters, and the emotions behind the story really gets to you. From the beautiful and light to the dark and depressing. 
+ a fox that barks 
+ It stays with you once you finished it. 

(possible) Negatives: 
+ The performance! It was a nightmare. I have a good PC that runs every game that came out this far but it's just horrible with this game. It keeps dropping frames, sometimes between 5-12! 
+ The puzzles. Although they're often fun, they can also get boring. It really depends if you're the type to enjoy repetitive tasks or not. 
+ You can feel at loss at first without knowing what to do. But once you get the pattern it gets easy. 

The story is bittersweet about love, loss and learning to live with the present. It's truly beautiful, and I definitely recommend it.

review: Gioco da 30 anni....E questo e' un capolavoro per due aspetti: una storia di un padre che perde un figlio..che ritrova nell'anima...un figlio che viaggia in una dimensione unica rappresentata con grafica stile fumetto,ma ricercata e accattivante. Il finale e' la sintesi dell'amore padre-figlio. Davvero un gran gioco,complimenti ai produttori e ovvio all'autore della colonna sonora

author: {'steamid': '76561198168922726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1603001169}
review: Controls great (using controller), beautiful, very simple, and the devs knew that they were making a game that only would have been bogged down by dialogue. This would make a great "Baby's First 3D Platformer" or use it to show someone who's skeptical about gaming as to why games can be fun and relaxing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151279692', 'num_games_owned': 552, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1602713953}
review:
Lots of dull walking while fox is barking at you annoyingly like a chiwawa. Unengaging gameplay. Decent visuals and music, that at points breefly succedes at building some sort of atmosphere.

As an alternative Ico-esque game I'd recommend you to check out Vane instead of this one. At the very least it won't waste as much of your time and money. And it manages to maintain the atmosphere and a decent pace of gameplay throughout.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970030638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1602438512}
review:

Unter dem Strich aber ist das Spiel sehr gelungen. Die Puzzles sind nicht allzu sehr schwer, bis man die Mechaniken verstanden hat. Und ja, die Grafik passt, sie tr√§gt sehr gut zur Stimmung bei.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044852113', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1601254776}
review:
A gorgeous game all around - gorgeous visuals, gorgeous music, gorgeous story. I really enjoyed playing this! I thought the story was great. I'm always impressed when a game can be moving and evoke emotions without any dialogue. I found the gameplay enjoyable as well.

That being said, I can see how this game isn't for everyone. It's not fast-paced, and there's no combat or anything like that - you're just exploring the world while trying to solve puzzles (a big plus for me, but could be a minus for others). Playing this game was a serene experience for me, and I would often find myself taking moments to stop and soak in the environment around me. So if you're not into playing a game that has a more relaxed pace/feel, you might not enjoy this as much as others. It's also on the shorter side (I beat it in about 8 1/2 hours, and I played it at a relaxed pace), so you might wanna wait for a sale.

Otherwise, I would absolutely recommend that you play RiME. It's beautiful all around. It's been a loooong time since a game has affected me like this one. I adore RiME, and it's one of my favorite experiences that I've had with a game in the past few years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198407459052', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1658028431}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971418402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1601039685}
review:
A very good game with good puzzles and music. There is no violence, but the setting is dark / sad. Especially on the end of the game.

If you'd like puzzles (games like Zelda for example), I would recommend this game to you. It's 6-7 hours of gameplay in total, but it's a very nice experience with the "story", puzzles and music.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972538954', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1600051650}
review:
I saw a lot of good stuff being said about this game. I had it on my wish list for a while. Got it for a buck. Finally picked it out of my backlog to play. 

I have to say I found it starkly disappointing. The gameplay and puzzles are bland and the story is only barely present. Even endgame revelations aren't particularly compelling. Each individual element of the game just made me think about all the games that have done them justice. To anyone considering this game, I suggest your time would be better spent with some obvious inspirations like Prince of Persia, ICO and Shadow of the Colossus. Don't get me wrong, it's a reasonably well put together game that looks alright and isn't outright broken (it does have camera issues and a handful of level design and gameplay sins) but it just wasn't interesting or engaging. I've got limited time to game and a huge backlog to play through so this one felt like a bit of a waste of time to me, even for a buck. It was especially disappointing given the great reviews it's received. I can't recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171948774', 'num_games_owned': 321, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1600039580}
review:
It was... ok.  The color scheme choices made the game painful on the eyes to play at times.  Maybe don't have the entire level be four slightly different shades of brown.  Doing platforming sections with dark grey on light black on dark black is not ideal.  It's ok to have more than one hue on the screen at a time.  From a puzzle/platforming aspect, a little more clarity as far as what the goal is would be nice maybe.  At least two hours of playtime were running around in circles because it wasn't clear that an area could be reached with existing abilities.

The soundtrack was nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129936651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 477, 'playtime_forever': 740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1599779771}
review:
RiME is an incredibly beautiful and heartfelt Adventure, Puzzle game. All right the story.

A young boy wakes up on a Mysterious Island, how did he get on the island, who built all these structures and more importantly where are the people? That is what he wants to know as he explores the land and tries to discover the truth.

So the likes, Well to start the game is incredibly beautiful starting with the levels from the warm grassy Hills and ocean to the ruins and desert valley to the rain-soaked land of chapter 4, there is just so much to see and explore. 

The game's atmosphere was very good and can be it can be beautiful or haunting or depressing and sometimes all at once.

The story is really, really good with all its themes and playing it a second time makes the story even better. Plus it's one of those games where there's no dialogue, it tells its story through actions and cutscenes which this game pulled off very well and this game is one of the few games to make me tear up.

The music in the game was incredibly beautiful to listen to especially the ending theme. The puzzles in the game were good and fairly difficult but not impossible to figure out. All those Collectibles you can get throughout the game was very cool like the keyhole collectibles.

Now the dislikes, the game is a bit short you can beat it in four hours, it only gets longer if you're going after the achievements. The price for the game is seriously too high for such a short game, I mean I could understand if the game was like 10 or $15 at most but 29,99 that is way too high. 

And lastly would I liked away to skip cutscenes I mean when I was going after the achievements I wish there was an option where I could just again skip the cutscenes.

Now with that said RiME is an incredibly beautiful and heartfelt Adventure, Puzzle game. With so much to love from the really, really good story, to the incredibly beautiful levels and the incredibly beautiful music.

Now if you‚Äôre looking for a Adventure, Puzzle game this is so for you, I highly recommended it but I say wait till it's on sale before you get it.

review:
Ho sottovalutato questo Rime, giocandolo quasi con sufficienza e catalogandolo, mentalmente, come uno di quei giochini che appagano l'occhio e poi, sotto sotto, non dicono nulla.
Mi sbagliavo enormemente.. Rime √® un gioco maturo che nasconde una delle cose pi√π tragiche e complesse della vita dipingendola e mascherandola con colori vivaci.
Tenete a portata di mano un fazzoletto, ne avrete bisogno..

Per chi pensa che i videogiochi possano essere, a tutti gli effetti, delle opere d'arte dico :  Rime ne √® un esemplare perfetto ! (altro che banana sul muro...)

(Grafica elegante con effetti di luce e riflessi di alto livello; comparto sonoro e musicale da capogiro)

review:
Games with this kind of aesthetic are usually horrible trash, but I keep finding myself buying them just in case they get it right.

RiME is the first to do so, and all the failed purchases I've made before justify this one. This game is beautiful and charming, and it effortlessly captures the essence of youthful adventure and imagination.

Well done!

author: {'steamid': '76561197975701227', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1597601392}
review:
hahahaha ... oh my goodness.

first up, this is a brilliant game, and for *anyone* that likes puzzlers, particularly platform puzzlers, particularly 3D platform puzzlers ... particularly bleak as fucking fuck puzzlers!

you owe it to yourself to complete this game. i just did, and i've not had many better endgames ...

author: {'steamid': '76561197970952979', 'num_games_owned': 2552, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1597711284}
review:
Absolutely beautiful from start to finish. Feels like a gentle version of Shadows of the Colossus, though without any Colossi. Make of that what you will.  It's the setting, the atmosphere, and the feeling that you're playing with ancient machinations you maybe shouldn't be.

This is one of those rare adventures that just is. You're told nothing, you just dive into the world you find yourself in and learn as you go, the scenery is gorgeous, vast and actively fascinating.  The story is silent, not a coherent word is ever said or written, and yet it really knows how to tug on a few chords in your heart before you know it.

There are some stunning set pieces and some superb animations that really carry a message stronger than words could.

There're no punishing elements to this game, any deaths I experienced (and a single glitch that stuck me in a wall and I had to restart), put me right back where I left off. There can feel like pressure and weight to your actions but failure is gently corrected.

The music is subtle but very mood-influencing!

It's a good modest length, I clocked 7 hours while barely scratching the achievements list


Biggest downside is it REALLY doesn't play well with my monitors and OBS, it took a long time of turning options on and off at random before it could settle. The option to select which monitor it's using is very confused - I had to select different monitors back and forth before it would eventually land on the one I wanted, even though the menus and resolution reported weren't even close!  I recommend turning down Shadow Detail as this seems to wreck performance and it looks great still

author: {'steamid': '76561198020928212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1596232263}
review:
Visuals - For the most part, this game does a great job of setting these grand backdrops without melting your GPU. I feel like the developer hit the perfect balance of keeping things visually appealing without compromising on performance. You're not going to be wowed by super complex textures or water physics, but game stays beautiful from beginning to end and runs great. What really stood out was how the gameplay elements (climable ledges, interactive objects, etc) fit in seamlessly with the surrounds; enough to make it seem like everything was supposed to be there but not so much that you weren't sitting around scratching your head wondering what to do or where to go

Story (NO SPOILERS) - I've seen a lot of developers try and capture the emotional tones of games like Journey and Abzu and completely wiff. Thankfully, TW knocked this one out of the park. Telling a story without dialogue or written words isn't new, but it's tricky. The overall theme only becomes apparent to the AFTER you beat the game but what blew me away was how well each section of the game complemented each other. There's optional collectibles that flesh out the narrative a bit as well. I missed most of them on my first playthrough but the game's length (~7 hours) and post-completion chapter select mean I'll probably try once or twice to find more.

Gameplay - The puzzles in RiME aren't difficult, but I don't think they're meant to be. The puzzles are there to give context to the narrative, and while they're not challenging they are pretty clever and satisfying to solve. There's some mild platforming in the form of some Nathan Drake esque ledge climbing but again, it's there to enhance the feeling of exploration. Overall movement and climbing was satisfying and it reminded me somewhat of a more responsive version of a Team Ico game (Shadow of the Colossus). I did appreciate how nice the camera movement felt. I can't count how many times I've played a game that tried to be "cinematic" and just resulted in me wrestling for control of the camera 90% of the time.

Overall 8.5/10 would recommend

author: {'steamid': '76561198035033104', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1596130789}

author: {'steamid': '76561198185977079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1595899435}
review:
I really enjoyed this game! I see some reviews online where people are judging the game against what they want it to be and it leaves them disappointed. The real question is, what is RiME TRYING to be, and does it accomplish what it sets out to do? To me, the answer is a resounding "yes" to that final question.

Graphically it is gorgeous. I have a mid-range PC and it ran silky smooth on high settings. I believe the performance issues they were having earlier on have been ironed out. I really love the art style in this game. The music/score is also top notch... really beautiful stuff that fits the game nicely. I also really liked the story. I've seen some complaints about the story not being explained or complex... but that's the point. The game is a journey of discovery where you have to piece it together. And when you finally do figure out what is going on, yes, it is a "simple" story, but it is powerful. A game doesn't need a dozen characters or voice acting to tell an effective story.

As for the puzzles, yes, they are not especially challenging, but they aren't trying to be. I enjoyed working my way through them and exploring the beautiful environments. I recently finished The Witness and it was one of my favorites, so I am not opposed to some good puzzling, but RiME is not trying to be a hard puzzle game. I did find some of the platforming a bit repetitive and the controls were not perfect, but they were more than sufficient.

So take RiME for what it is, a beautiful journey of discovery with some fun but not overly difficult challenges along the way. For an indy game, I think it is a triumph.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003943149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1595669243}
review:
I loved this game in the first one hour. Stunning, mysterious, lets you explore a big world with the wind in your face. It felt great.

Then I continued playing and realised the "puzzles" are still as simple as they were in the beginning, the exploration is actually just a linear path which you are not rewarded for, and the big world isn't really utilised except for some nice views.

It stopped being compelling and became a chore to just walk down these silly pointless caverns and staircases while shouting at the lights for no reason. One of the biggest shifts in game enjoyments I've had. I certainly don't recommend it.

And the full price tag is obnoxious. Only try this on a steep sale, and don't base it off the first 20 minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961142450', 'num_games_owned': 1736, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1595383130}
review:
This game is a gem.  It's perfect for both experienced and novice gamers alike.  For the experienced, it is a beautiful and relatively stress free action-platformer with plenty of environmental puzzles in the vein of Zelda and Assassin's Creed.  For the novices, it is a great way to understand modern game mechanics in an environment that doesn't punish failure.  

I played this game with my fiancee who up until a year ago had never really played a video game.  With a bit of ongoing assistance she was able to truly begin to feel comfortable with a controller in her hand.  The ability to manipulate a character and camera in 3D space with an unfamiliar control scheme is a lot for newbies.  This game does an excellent job of holding their hand, while also still making the gamer feel smart.

I fully recommend this game for couples looking for a game they can play together.  I also recommend it to anybody that wants to enjoy a laid back 8 hour experience that will leave them feeling positive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020789907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 969, 'last_played': 1594788023}
review:
RiME is a good game that can be interpreted in many different ways depending on how you gather information from the world in the game. There are puzzles and platforming to do for the most part of the game but those are clearly not the focus of the game, they are well-made but not incredible. The best part about RiME is about how you put together a story easily if you can perceive what's happening to the character and the world that you traverse. 

I think that the fun at least for me was trying to understand the big picture and if you are not in it for that it might leave you disappointed. The quality of the game is overall good I didn't get stuck and finding out where to go next was easy. It's not a game that is so abstract that it basically feels like there isn't a story but more about giving you signs and leaving the interpretation up to you. The ending of the game is pretty gut wrenching and while my interpretation of the story was totally different at first once you understand what was going on during the whole game it hits pretty hard. 

I think it's a game worth playing if what I described is something you'd enjoy, the price tag is in the higher end of the spectrum for a game in this category I won't discuss it, it's kind of the point of reading reviews anyways right?

Se vi piacciono i puzzle/platform di esplorazione con tantissimi collezionabili, compratelo a occhi chiusi. Se vi piacciono le storie toccanti e le atmosfere evocative, idem. Menzione d'onore per la grafica, disegni e colori sono fantastici, e alcuni personaggi sembrano usciti da un film di Miyazaki. L'ultimo livello con la pioggia √® a dir poco affascinante.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001211770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1220, 'last_played': 1595237690}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024663779', 'num_games_owned': 403, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1595194894}
review:
Rime is a great adventure game with platforming and puzzles.  You're  a boy who finds himself washed up on the shore of a beach. You make your way inland and find a fox along the way. The fox guides you where to go as you work your way throughout the game. The game is around six hours long if you don't search every nook and cranny for collectibles. The platforming and puzzles are pretty easy so just about anybody can complete the game, but they're still challenging enough to keep you engaged throughout the game. 

The art, the music, and atmosphere that they create goes perfectly with the story the developers are trying to tell. The way this game is presented made it easy to be immersed in it. Some people may not be impressed with the art style of this game but I think it will age well as time goes on. The game is quite cinematic and every scene is directed well.Rime is about dealing with loss in life and the music is used to highlight that. 

I would recommend this game to anybody looking for a game that doesn't require a lot of time or effort to get through. Gameplay is simple enough to keep you from getting stuck and engaging enough to keep you interested.  I found it a bit relaxing and a very enjoyable experience. 

Overall:9/10

Presentation: 10/10
Visuals: 8/10
Music: 10/10
Gameplay:8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197991315919', 'num_games_owned': 1913, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1595006091}
review:
Rime is a game where you are going to face a lot of beauties and a lot of clever story tellings and a lot of emotions.
This game is like Papo Yo a rather short story puzzle game.
Telling a story through the form of a world with many puzzles that when solved allow for the progress that gives you a bit more of the story.
Again like Papo Yo the story is told visually and not through words and with that you have a lot of different symbolism in place and the whole story does not unfold until the very end showing what was really happening.
The game is beautiful to look at, the style is pleasing, the sounds and music evoke all kinds of emotions and the story heart rending.
Give it a try if you can, I probably would not have picked it up if I knew what the game's story is about but I am glad that I went in blind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003306082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1595050057}
review:
I have mixed feelings about this game.

The first two of four (the fifth level is a glorified cutscene) levels are amazing.  Beautiful, platforming, puzzles, lots of secrecy and mystery through exploration.  The third level is the "Water Temple" x 3.  It's confusing, and it doesn't know what it wants to be throughout the entire level.  Is it a maze?  Oh, the maze part is done.  Is it an avoid the evil creatures?  Oh, the evil creatures part is done.  Is it lead the drone through the ancient puzzle areas?  Yes.

The final level lacks any of the beauty of the other levels.  it rains the entire time and the level is all stone black.

The game also has a story.  It's not necessary at all, and for me it's what makes the game mixed for me.  If they threw the story out the window and gave me the same first two levels but five different times, then the story just wouldn't matter.  But they have a story and thus fit mechanics into said story:

[spoiler] You play a son who died during a storm at sea who is searching for his father.  Each of the five levels emulate the five stages of grief.  So while the first two levels emulate denial and aggression, which fit really well into the game, the third and fourth levels emulate bargaining and depression.  I guess I felt those during the levels?  But it was so poorly done at the third and fourth levels that the end did not pay off.  The fifth level is "Acceptance", which means you simply press W a few times to walk through a hall and let a scarf go.[/spoiler]

Overall, I spent about 5 hours in the first two levels, having fun.  The third level I spent 3 hours in, confused out of my damn mind, and the fourth and fifth level speeding through clocking a whole 1 hour about.

No payoff and I steel fill a bit empty.

Still, I'd recommend buying it.  It was fun while it lasted and makes me long for games like the Legend of Zelda and such.

author: {'steamid': '76561198377276758', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1681378214}
review: Actually made me cry real tears. A powerful experience, and a pleasant platformer game to boot. Very visually appealing, overall very good. Some of the puzzles aren't very intuitive, but the reward of the story and ending is worth it, 100%.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004566061', 'num_games_owned': 1371, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 993, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1594786371}
review: Like Limbo, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons, or Journey, Rime is a peak in visual storytelling. The locations are beautiful and full of detail, with each chapter being very visually distinct. There were a lot of interesting puzzle mechanics introduced over the course of the game; the puzzles themsevles were on the easier side but served the pacing of the story well. As a fan of the genre, I really enjoyed the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027805196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1594514044}
review:
This, more than any other game I have played, is an overwhelming testament to the fact that any game in any genre can and will be made to be about sad dads. I'm sick of games about sad dads. 

Pretty, atmospheric, overwrought, and its pitifully short length inflated by slow movement and somehow aimless railroading. Whatever type of game you're after, this almost certainly isn't it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079456686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 764, 'last_played': 1594419668}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063817153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1594397344}
review:
RiME es una obra bell√≠sima, muy bien orquestada y original, a pesar de que hay otros juegos en los que se inspira. El punto fuerte de RiME es su sentimentalismo (envuelto en el misterio de su historia), sin olvidar sus gr√°ficos preciosistas y su tremenda banda sonora.

Los puzles no son complicados, pues el juego no pretende ser un gran desaf√≠o ni atascar a los jugadores demasiado tiempo, sino que est√° pensado para que el que lo juegue vaya disfrutando sin frustraciones, con un ritmo din√°mico y enlazando poco a poco pedacitos de la historia en los elementos que va encontrando en el mapa o las secuencias de v√≠deo (los extras no son imprescindibles para pasar el juego, sin embargo aportan informaci√≥n importante para entender la historia). En resumen se trata de un juego corto (unas 10 horas si no nos detenemos mucho a explorar todo o hasta 30 o mas si queremos completar todo). La Historia es el gran misterio que hay que desvelar. El √∫nico "pero" es el de sus problemas de rendimiento (FPS o ca√≠da de frames/cuadros), solucionado ya casi por completo con parches. Sin embargo, si has jugado juegos antiguos con muchos elementos en pantalla, las ralentizaciones entonces (Nes 8 bits, etc) eran mucho peores y no nos privaban de jugar magn√≠ficos juegos. En mi experiencia personal no me afectaba ya que ocurr√≠a de vez en cuando, y con menos frecuencia a partir del segundo capitulo (lo he jugado completo en Nintendo Switch antes del parche que lo mejora much√≠simo). Es un diminuto gran juego, que pasar√° a ser una obra maestra con el paso del tiempo, aunque para m√≠ ya lo es. INOLVIDABLE. Lo estoy jugando de nuevo en PC ahora que lo acabo de comprar en edici√≥n f√≠sica (DvD). Editado: "Hace bien poco que lo volvi a terminar en su version de Xbox One, la mejor de todas, graficos al maximo y suavidad en fps, inolvidable, jugado en una Series S".

author: {'steamid': '76561198841154287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1594346078}
review: Visually beautiful, poignant storytelling. My only complaint is that there isn't more. Moderately challenging puzzles, very forgiving movement dynamics (dying never matters...or does it?), and overall an incredible, immersive little game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198376618844', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1594299709}
review: On the lines of games like Journey or ABZU, this is a very sweet title, with a strong atmosphere and gameplay. I encountered a couple of bugs, but nothing that a "Load from last checkpoint" couldn't fix. The story is not obvious, but collecting secrets helps understanding it, and it's a pretty strong one. Love the musical score, absolutely amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198358805829', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1488, 'last_played': 1627942528}
review:
RiME √© um jogo simplesmente incr√≠vel!
Voc√™ acorda perdido em uma ilha m√°gica onde precisa explorar os cen√°rios e resolver alguns puzzles ao longo da hist√≥ria para entender seus mist√©rios.
Trilha sonora fant√°stica o que torna a experi√™ncia de jogo muito tranquila e relaxante, sem falar na qualidade gr√°fica que tamb√©m √© excelente.
A cada cap√≠tulo conclu√≠do √© revelado um flashback sobre o que aconteceu, o que desperta cada vez mais vontade de jogar para descobrir o seu desfecho.
RiME tem um final sensacional, que para mim, foi inesperado e muito emocionante!
Vale muito a pena, tenho certeza que n√£o ir√° arrepender-se!
Recomendo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003407797', 'num_games_owned': 348, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1594144234}
review: I wish we had more games like this. Something with actual meaning, not just mindless violence. This game was such an enjoyable journey to take and the ending is among the best I have seen. The standouts for me were the art direction and the music, but everything else about this is great too. Sale or no sale, get this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198797143205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1416, 'last_played': 1594792194}
review:
To be honest, This game can get very boring. However if you love puzzles , I'd highly  recommend  purchasing it.  The visuals are excellent and the overall story is great. I also LOVED the  design of the protagonist.  Something seems lacking though.  You interact with the world using your voice and carrying things. When that's not the case, you're just climbing. Given the ultimate twist to the entire game, I feel like it could have been a lot more adventurous. The overall themes have  various interpretations that  would have allowed  for many potential enemies and allies. While what we got was ok, I feel  it was a little uninspired.  I started to want to do more than jump from ledge to ledge and scream "Hah!"  Or carry glowing orbs around.  If you need  a little guidance even in a sandbox setting, you're fresh out of luck.   It's entirely possible to a puzzle wrong and have to start a stage over to remedy that. You're going to have to find  a good online guide.  The closest thing this game has to that is a little fox that barks at you and even so, you'll need to solve a puzzle to get him.  I purchased this game while it was on sale. I recommend doing that.

It isn;t worth thirty dollars. A game worth that amount  would have not only created a beautiful world but   would also have given me an adventure to have in it. I feel cheated. Like I got to travel to paradise  but was trapped in a linear bubble with aggravating puzzles.  I also don't know enough about the characters to feel  much of anything for them. I understand that being abstract is necessary for the reveal but  some character details would have helped tremendously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180958430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1594083599}
review: es una hermosura de juego altamente recomendado y con ese final ufffff, de verdad comprenlo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009743689', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1594003372}
review:
I followed the advice of the first review I saw that said to not read anything about this game before I played it, I knew absolutely nothing about it except that it was similar to other puzzle platformers I enjoyed. I regret nothing. 

Don't watch any gameplay, don't look at the community hub, don't even let the trailer play. This game is most beautiful when you can discover it piece by piece on your own. The only advice I will give is that while I normally ignore object collection side quests, this game makes it worth going out of your way for. Try and explore as much as you can.

I hope you enjoy the journey as much as I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004313985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1593937992}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027990230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1593899578}
review:
Amazing art direction, music and atmosphere. The gameplay is pure plataforming with mostly easy and some harder puzzles here and there, but that's not this game's focus. There is a really story told visually throughout the game and you may experience some strong feels towards the end.

It's a short game, lasting somewhere between 7-10h, depending if you are just following the story or going after the extras and achievments (and the extras do add some nice lore to the story). It's usualy a little too expensive for the length of the game, but it's a great purchase in summer/winter sale.

review:
Rime is a beautiful game.

It took me seven hours to beat Rime. This is mostly a game of interesting but not very difficult puzzles - there are a few action sequences, and some secrets you can find, but the main thing is the experience, not the challenge. If that sounds like something you'll enjoy you should play Rime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004976067', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 20, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1711822985}
review:
It pains me to give this game a negative review.  It is, after all, a gorgeous game, and I must admit, I was captivated by it almost the entire way through.  But there are two things I really didn't like about this game.

The first was that most of the puzzles weren't interesting, once you are introduced to their mechanics.  Basically, the game will introduce a puzzle mechanic, and the first puzzle might be somewhat confusing, but after that, almost all puzzles are straightforward variations of it.  Some aren't even puzzles so much as busy work, especially climbing sequences.

I could excuse this defect because the game has really gorgeous aesthetics to it, and the protagonists, despite the lack of words, have endearing qualities to them.

The thing that really annoyed me about this game is the following.  About 3/4ths of the way through the game, I mentioned to my wife, "I really hope that [hackneyed plot twist] isn't true."

And waddya know?  It turned out to be true!

And that was so disappointing, not just because it has been done to death, but because it does not serve to tie any of the other game's elements together.  Frankly, the game would have done better to leave you in the dark to form your own hypotheses.  Instead, it clumsily attempts to hit you over the head with its "big reveal," but misses by a mile.

What follows is my opinion, which slightly gives this away, and so I will shroud most of it in a spoiler:

I think this game suffers from what a lot of media suffers from these days: the need to be deep by over-explaining things.  Professor X can't just have gone bald, because Male-Pattern Baldness is a thing.  He has to have lost his boyish mop of hair after being strapped into a machine of death.  Han Solo can't just be named Han Solo, because it's just a name.  No, he has to acquire it, because he "goes it, alone." (and, for some reason, people in a galaxy far, far, away are aware of Spanish).  In this case, [spoiler]you can't just have a child truly journey through a mysterious island with ancient technology, and unconventional topology.  No, it has to turn out to be "like a deep metaphor for loss, and grief, man."  Give me a break.  If you're going to do that, at least do it well.  Have the Fox, the scary bird thing, and the ancient walking robots be symbolic of this.[/spoiler]  Instead, we get what amounts to a hairy dog story in video game form, and that really does the rest of the  game a disservice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965768605', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1593566269}
review:
Pros: beautiful game that reminds Journey, easy to grasp, nice ending.

Cons: way too short, too pricey, the puzzles are too easy, not really inspired, and there is no replayability. Wait for the Steam sales if you want to try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015887960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 753, 'last_played': 1593511942}
review:
I need a permission slip for this feels trip. 

Beautiful artwork and amazing soundtrack. I normally turn music off in games, but doing that here would be a terrible mistake. While it's a short game, it's definitely worth taking your time to enjoy the world.

Game plays somewhat like Uncharted or Tomb Raider without the combat, so basically exploration/climbing and puzzles. The story is also very tied to the presentation of the levels and there are quite a few metaphors once you figure out what's going on. Definitely a worthwhile experience. Just be prepared to feel things.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983290992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1594169444}
review:
Okay... let's go easy now. "Rime" is not the game you may think it is at first. If you're expecting a casual, relaxing walking simulator, "Rime" is not quite that. Because in order for a game to be that, it wouldn't ask so much from its players as "Rime" does. Most of its puzzles are fair enough, but some others can be really brain-wrecking and time consuming. So this is the first thing to learn about this game: it's not so casual as it looks. It will take you some time; my first run in it took me close to six hours.

The game is very much a semi-open world, with these large areas. There's very little to indicate you where to go, since the game goes for minimalism, but it surely could use a way to at least point players where to go next, like in "BioShock: Infinite", "Alien: Isolation" and even "Mirror's Edge". For "Rime", there's this fox that barks at you, pointing you where to go in bigger areas. And sometimes, there'll be lights coming from the ground into the sky like beacons. Those are helpful, but a bit cumbersome; a mini-map could have aided much.

As a puzzle game, it has its fair share of classic key fetching, and sometimes you'll need to carry small objects to complete your goals. You'll also be dragging larger blocks around like in a "Tomb Raider" game. One little problem with the game is that it can have some annoying backtracking, as once you activate something, you're required to walk your way back into where you've been before. It's not something that happens often, but it's a noticeable issue nonetheless.

The game is heavy on puzzles, but one big thing about "Rime" is the platforming. There's a lot of jumping and climbing to do in this game, and controls are fluid and reliable - except however when you need to drop down from some higher ground, as landing from certain altitudes will stun your character for a bit. There's also a lot of swimming in this game, but underwater environments can get very big and very disorienting, while you can only hold your breath for so long.

This brings me to something important: you can actually die in this game. Falling from large heights and drowning are the ways the environment can kill you. As for enemies, you'll come across the "shades": sinister creatures in dark hoods who are harmless at first, but become dangerous later on. In a level, you'll also see this giant bird that can poach you if you stay in the open for too long. The good news however is that once you die, you immediately pick up from close nearby, meaning that you don't lose anything at all. The deaths in this game will be more of a nuisance than a heavy frustration.

The visuals are splendid, and many compared them to "Breath of the Wild": it doesn't go for ultra-realism, but instead for painting-like graphics that are exuberant and evocative. It even feels like those short animated films you see in YouTube. The thing however - and I don't think this is something all players experienced or will experience - is that my PC would get really hot while playing this game, to the point I could personally feel it. And this scared the hell out of me, more than any of the enemies or visuals in this game. I toned the graphics down, but even then my PC would still heat up like a fireplace. It's weird that happens for a game in which the visuals don't even look that demanding.

There are plenty of collectables in this game - so much in fact that to call this game a collectaton wouldn't be so far off. Some of these collectables are easy to find, but others are very well hidden, representing massive detours from the main path. After you beat the game, you can access the levels individually at the main menu to pick up what you missed. There's also a lot of achievements, so this game will keep completionists busy for a time. You can even unlock new clothes for your character, but they're just cosmetic; it would have been nice if different clothes would bring certain benefits.

Speaking of your character, this is when I address the story, and I left it for last for a reason. I won't spoil anything, but I'll just say that the main idea of this game was treated clumsily. It tries to tell a story in a symbolic fashion, but at some flashbacks, the game kind of lies to us in order not to reveal itself so soon. And the game is so minimalist with its storytelling (not a word is uttered throughout the whole game) that some players might not even get it after concluding it. The story itself is quite noble and surprisingly profound, but I wish its themes were treated better.

"Rime" is a flawed gem of a game. It is much more than its visuals alone, and you should definitely buy it if you're a fan of puzzles, platformers and collectatons. It assimilates all that is familiar to us in its own unique way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271621062', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1593183659}
review:
Like Limbo or Inside - without the scares.

If you have like games like Limbo and Inside, you will most certainly love this one. The only stage which left me depressed was Depression itself... you are in a dark, rainy, lugubrious night and you will have to make your way through to shining beacons while navigating through a ghoul filled labyrinth. (The ghouls do not kill you or harm you).

If you are used to playing such games, this will take no longer than 6-7 hours. If you are a casual gamer like me and like to enjoy the scenery and have some screen grabs of really fantastic scenery, this will take a little more time.

The puzzles are a lot of fun too! There are times where you need to run about, but that just makes it a little more exciting.

Definitely worth a dekko!
